repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Telecommunications and Postal
            Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Telecommunications and
            Postal Sector Reform Project for Algeria were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: competition, brought about by liberalization in
            the telecommunications sector, is the most effective driver
            for sector performance. Consistent and strong political
            support is critical in a project that aims to introduce more
            private sector participation in the postal and
            telecommunications sector, especially in an economy that has
            long been driven by Government intervention. In a project
            supporting telecommunications sector liberalization, an
            upfront solid institutional communication strategy is needed
            to convey and rally all stakeholders, in particular the
            unions to the strategic objectives of the reform and the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Algeria - Telecommunications and Postal
            Sector Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Telecommunications and Postal Sector
            Reform Project aims to create an enabling environment to
            improve access to efficient and affordable communications
            services by opening the telecommunications and postal
            sectors to competition and private participation. The
            project consists of six components: 1) The first component
            will finance international consultants to establish a new
            legal and regulatory framework and enact secondary
            legislation which will cover organization and functioning of
            regulatory authority, competition, licensing,
            interconnection, etc. 2) The second component will implement
            gradual liberalization of policy in the sector by financing
            a detailed transaction strategy for the award of the Global
            System for Mobil Communication (GSM) licenses. 3) The third
            component will help restructure the Ministry of Posts and
            Telecommunications (MPT). A consultancy will assist the
            Government with the separation of the telecommunications and
            postal operations from the MPT. 4) The fourth component will
            finance a detailed transaction and marketing strategy for
            the privatization of the Telecommunications entity. 5) The
            fifth component will elaborate a comprehensive postal
            development strategy focusing on long term competitiveness
            and modernization of the postal work. 6) The last component
            will strengthen communication strategy and capacity building
            by informing potential investors on new business
            opportunities and ensure transparency of the reform program.
